channel.title: Shopping System
channel.description:
So I would like to get some advice on how you personally believe the shopping system should be done. I will be taking Sinisoul's advice about using the configs already done (I'm not big on putting items in shops anyway so the normal RS shops is plenty for me )
What I am wondering about though is exactly how the anti dupe/cheat engine be set up? I don't know a whole lot about cheat engines.
What would you also suggest for maximum performance?

I recommend turDkill4hs anti-dupe engine, it’s purpose built for this sort of thing in mind. It uses polynomially distributed hash tables with A* lookup mechanisms, and even has an e-commerce bounce-submission detector.

item.title: Shopping System
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

The reason I don’t like what sinisoul posted is that it really does leave a lot of potential to mess up the shop system if you aren’t 100% careful with all of the code you write. You’re letting the client create the shop items, which to me doesn’t really make sense. In any shop anti-dupe system you’re going to need to have the shop items saved server-sided anyways, so there’s no real point to use the configs he posted.

That said, here are some things you need to make sure you have that relate to anti-dupes and anti-cheats in shops:

  1. Make sure the player has physical access to the shop in question. This is usually handled in your NPC/Object interaction packet handlers.
  2. Have a player variable that keeps track of the store the player currently has open, this is much easier than creating a Shop instance for each player. Set this to -1 or whatever when they do any action that closes the shop (closing the interface, walking away, etc)
  3. Store the item amounts and prices on the server… each shop should have this.
